Some features:

1) Processor: MediaTek Dimensity 810 5G

2) Operating system: ‎Android 11

3) RAM: ‎8 GB

4) ROM: 128 GB

5) Display: 6.78 inches

This phone is available in four colours: blue haze, grey sierra, green woods and PAC man. It also comes in two variants - 8GB RAM+128GB storage and 12GB RAM+256GB storage. For this discussion, we ha considered 8GB RAM+128GB storage in colour blue haze.

column9: Moto G71 Tipped To Debut in India Next Week: Report | 📲 LatestLY
column10:
Motorola India is tipped to launch the Moto G71 smartphone in India next week. As a reminder, the handset made its global debut last year, along with Moto G31, Moto G41, Moto G51 and Moto G200 phones. Moto G51 and G31 have already made their debut in India, and now, it's time for the G71 device. Tipster Yogesh Brar has revealed on his Twitter account that the company could launch the Moto G71 device by the second week of this month but did not reveal the exact date. He has also revealed that the company will start teasing the smartphone by the end of this week. Moto G51 With Snapdragon 480+ SoC Launched; Check Price, Features & Specifications.

Moto G71 is likely to get a 6.4-inch FHD+ OLED display with a resolution of 2400x1080 pixels. The device might come powered by Qualcomm Snapdragon 695 SoC coupled with 8GB of RAM and 128GB of internal storage. For clicking photographs, it could feature a 50MP main lens, an 8MP ultra-wide-angle lens and a 2MP macro shooter. Upfront, there is a 16MP selfie camera.

The handset is said to be fuelled by a 5,000mAh battery with a 30W fast charging facility. So we expect the Indian pricing of the device to be somewhere around it.

column9: OnePlus 9RT to launch in India soon; company confirms in a cryptic post
column10:
In two consecutive tweets from its official Twitter account, OnePlus India teased the OnePlus 9RT and OnePlus Buds Z2 on January 2, 2022. Read details here.

OnePlus 9RT has been recently teased by OnePlus India, confirming the smartphone release in the country. The smartphone was launched by OnePlus in its native market back in October 2021, along with the OnePlus Buds Z2 truly wireless earphones. In November 2021, the smartphone was spotted on the OnePlus Care App, carrying the name OnePlus RT. However, as OnePlus reveals the OnePlus 9RT in India, older smartphones such as the OnePlus 9, the OnePlus 9R and the OnePlus 8T might be discontinued soon after the launch.

In two consecutive tweets from its official Twitter account, OnePlus India teased the upcoming products on January 2, 2022. Interestingly, both the tweets contain encoded messages in Morse Code. While several netizens decoded the message using online decrypters, the code in the first tweet refers to OnePlus 9RT and the code in the second tweet refers to the OnePlus Buds Z2. However, this is all that has been revealed by the company, not announcing the OnePlus 9RT 5G India launch date.

The OnePlus 9RT comes with Samsung's E4 AMOLED display, which also supports a 120Hz fast refresh rate. On the inside, the smartphone will be powered by Qualcomm's flagship Snapdragon 888 chipset, which is one of the fastest processors for mobile phones in the Android ecosystem. Both the OnePlus 9 and OnePlus 9 Pro run on the same chipset. Additionally, the company has also fitted in LPDDR5 RAM and UFS 3.1 storage in the device, which is available in variants with 128GB of storage and either 6 or 8GB of RAM.

The OnePlus 9RT features a 4,500 mAh battery, which shall be enough for a typical day of usage. Since the device has a superior display and processor, a heavy user might have to charge the smartphone by the evening. As the battery also supports 65W fast charging, it is highly likely that the smartphone will ship with the fast charger in the box. In terms of cameras, the OnePlus 9RT features a triple rear camera setup, with a 50MP main sensor. The new OnePlus device seems to fill the gap between the OnePlus 9R and the OnePlus 9.

column9: OnePlus 9RT & Buds Z2 Teased Online, India Launch Soon | 📲 LatestLY
column10:
After launching in China, OnePlus is now all set to launch the 9RT and Buds Z2 in India soon. Last month, the OnePlus 9Rt and Buds Z2 were reportedly spotted on the OnePlus India website. Now, the company has teased the arrival of both the devices via two mysterious tweets, which contain Morse codes. The Morse code in the first tweet translates to OnePlus 9RT, whereas the second tweet reveals OnePlus Buds Z2. Apart from this, both tweets do not reveal much information. OnePlus 9RT & OnePlus Buds Z2 Spotted on India Website, Launch Expected Soon.

OnePlus 9RT and Buds Z2 will arrive in India with similar specifications as that of the Chinese model. The 9RT will get a 6.62-inch FHD+ Fluid AMOLED display with a resolution of 2400x1080 pixels and a refresh rate of 120Hz.

The handset will come powered by Qualcomm Snapdragon 888 SoC coupled with up to 12GB of RAM and 256GB of internal storage.

For optics, it will get a triple rear camera setup comprising a 50MP Sony IMX766 sensor, a 16MP ultra-wide-angle lens and a 2MP macro shooter. At the front, there will be a 16MP snapper for selfies and video calls. The device will run on Android 11 or Android 12 OS and will pack a 4,500mAh battery with 65W rapid charging.

On the other hand, OnePlus Buds Z2 will get 11mm bass-tuned dynamic drivers, Bluetooth v5.2 support and active noise cancellation. The earbuds will come with up to 38 hours of battery life, touch controls and a transparency mode. The charging case will pack a 520mAh battery that will be charged with the help of a USB Type-C port.

column9: Best mobile phones under 40000 in January 2022: Oppo Reno 6 Pro and iQOO 7 Legend among top choices
column10:
The OnePlus 9R features a 6.55-inch AMOLED display and supports a 120Hz refresh rate.

Are you looking for a new smartphone within the range of Rs. 40,000? Within this price bracket, you can find several premium offerings from brands such as OnePlus, Xiaomi, Oppo among others.

Most of these smartphones, under Rs 40,000 offer users some great features, some of which were earlier only available on flagship devices earlier at a reasonable price. These smartphones offer great performance, cameras, and 5G support. So here is our list of the best mobile phones you can buy in January 2022 under Rs. 40,000.

Oppo Reno 6 Pro

The Oppo Reno 6 Pro is available for Rs. 39,990. It has a splendid design that the company calls the Reno Glow design. It uses AG Glass that has undergone a dedicated process to impart a matte finish with a shiny appearance. It features a 6.55-inch Full-HD+ AMOLED display with curved edges on both sides and has a 90Hz refresh rate.

It is powered by an octa-core MediaTek Dimensity 1200 processor paired with 12GB of RAM. The Oppo Reno 6 Pro 5G comes with a 64-megapixel primary camera. An 8-megapixel ultrawide camera and the 2-megapixel macro camera. Moreover, the smartphone is powered by a 4500 mAh battery with support for 65W fast charging.

Our Verdict: The Oppo Reno 6 Pro offers a splendid design, fast performance, fast battery charging, and a sharp and bright display. However, it misses out on dual stereo speakers and has no support for 4K 60 fps videos.

You can read our detailed review here.

iQOO 7 Legend

The iQOO 7 Legend is available for Rs. 39,990. It sports a striking white colour with a matte finish with the iconic tri-colour racing stripes of BMW M Motorsport running all through the back of the phone as a highlight. It features a 6.62 inch 120Hz AMOLED display with 2400 x 1080 pixels resolution, 398 PPI pixel density, and 1300 nits of peak brightness.

The smartphone is powered by a Qualcomm Snapdragon 888 processor. There is a triple camera setup with a 48-megapixel primary camera with a Sony IMX598 sensor, a 13-megapixel wide-angle camera with a 120-degree field of view, and a black and white Mono camera with 2x optical zoom at the back.

Our Verdict: The iQOO 7 Legend is a strong contender in the sub Rs 40,000 price range. It offers great camera performance, large RAM, and a fast processor.

You can read our detailed review here.

OnePlus 9R

The OnePlus 9R is currently available for Rs. 39,990. It features a 6.55-inch AMOLED display and supports a 120Hz refresh rate. The OnePlus 9R is an excellent gaming companion, and you won't be bothered about heat issues because it features several gaming-related features, including a 14 temperature sensor to monitor the device's temperature.

The OnePlus 9R ships with a 4500mAh battery and supports 65W fast charging. It comes with a 48-megapixel primary Sony IMX586 sensor with f/1.7 aperture and EIS we saw on the 8T. There's also a 16-megapixel ultra-wide camera with a 123-degree field of view. The phone packs a 5-megapixel macro sensor and a 2-megapixel monochrome sensor.

Our Verdict: The OnePlus 9R offers decent camera performance, a bright and responsive display as well as fast charging support. It is a good option for gamers as it comes with several gaming-related features.

You can read our detailed review here.

Mi 11X Pro

The Mi 11X Pro is currently available for Rs. 36,999. It looks exactly the same as the Mi 11X. The phone is only 7.8mm thick and weighs 196 grams. It comes with a 6.67-inch FHD+ Super AMOLED display with a 120Hz refresh rate. The Mi 11X Pro is powered by a Qualcomm Snapdragon 888 processor paired with 8GB of LPDDR5 RAM and up to 256GB of UFS 3.1 storage.

The Mi 11X Pro runs MIUI 12.0.1 on top of Android 11. Xiaomi makes use of a 108-megapixel primary rear camera, an 8-megapixel ultrawide unit with an f/2.2 aperture, and a 5-megapixel tele macro lens with an f/2.4 aperture. It packs a 4520 mAh battery along with support for 33W fast charging.

You can read our detailed review here.

Our Verdict: The Mi 11X Pro comes with a good display, a capable camera system, the best processor, and a very pretty colour option. It is slim, stylish, and offers extremely good value for money.

column9: POCO M4 launch timeline and specifications tipped: 90Hz display, 64MP triple cameras, and more | 91mobiles.com
column10:
POCO M3 was launched in India back in February 2021 with Snapdragon 662 SoC, 48MP triple cameras, and up to 6GB RAM. Since we're nearing a year since its announcement, the company appears to be gearing up to launch a successor to it, dubbed as the POCO M4. It should come as a cheaper alternative to the POCO M4 Pro that debuted globally in November. The POCO M4 launch date and specifications have been tipped, courtesy of an exclusive report from MySmartPrice citing noted leakster Mukul Sharma. We can speculate the handset will replace the POCO M3 in a similar price range.

POCO M3 will launch in the global and Asian markets around early February, according to Mukul Sharma. This may include India as well, but it isn't specified explicitly at the moment.

Moving to the specifications, POCO M4 is said to launch with a 90Hz refresh rate, likely on an LCD panel similar to the predecessor. Powering the device will be a MediaTek processor, but the exact chipset details are unknown at the moment. The POCO M4 will have a triple camera setup on the back, with a 64MP OV64B40 sensor, 8MP IMX355 sensor, and a 2MP OV2A lens. it will run on Android 11 OS with MIUI 12.5 custom skin on top.

That's pretty much it about the POCO M4 at the moment but we should learn more details as we inch closer to the launch date.

The POCO M3 will replace the POCO M4 in the brand's portflio. To recall the specifications of the former, it sports a 6.53-inch FHD+ display with a waterdrop notch and a standard 60Hz refresh rate. The phone is powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 662 SoC paired with up to 6GB RAM and 128GB storage that is further expandable.

The POCO M3 has triple cameras at the back, with a 48MP primary sensor, a 2MP depth sensor for portrait shots, and a 2MP macro lens for close-up shots. For selfies and video chats, there is an 8MP on the front.

column9: CES 2022 to be held in hybrid mode; here's what to expect
column10: The likes of Amazon, Intel, AMD, Nvidia, Microsoft, Lenovo, Meta, Twitter, and Google have announced they will take part in the event virtually. These companies will live-stream press conferences and host digital exhibits rather than hosting the event in person. In contrast, Samsung, Sony, LG and Qualcomm plan to attend the event physically. Thousands of top leaders from federal and state and foreign governments, entrepreneurs, businesses, media, and buyers plan to come to Las Vegas for CES. "We have received several thousand new registrants since late last week. Given CES' comprehensive health measures - vaccination requirement, masking and availability of COVID-19 tests - coupled with lower attendance and social distancing measures, we are confident that attendees and exhibitors will have a socially distanced but worthwhile and productive event," the organisers added.

column9: realme: Realme GT 2 Pro to launch tomorrow: Everything that we know about the smartphone
column10:
Vivo Y21T with 50MP camera, 5000mAh battery launched in India: Price, Specs and moreRealme is all set to launch the Realme GT 2 series tomorrow (January 4) and ahead of the launch the company's vice president Xu Qi has revealed more details about the device. The GT 2 Pro series is rumoured to comprise two smartphones - Realme GT 2 and Realme GT 2 Pro. In a post on Weibo, the executive has revealed that the device will get a 32MP front-facing camera and 50MP dual-cameras at the rear. The post also reveals that the Realme GT2 will be equipped with a 2K AMOLED display, surrounded by slim bezels.

Talking about the Realme GT 2 Pro, the brand has already confirmed that the smartphone will be powered by the newly launched Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 chipset. Key specs of the device have already been leaked in various leaks and rumours.

When it comes to the design, Realme claims that the Realme GT 2 Pro will be the world's first smartphone to be designed with bio-based materials. As per the company, the back cover on the smartphone uses a bio-polymer material that serves as an eco-friendly alternative to fossil raw materials that contribute to global warming. The device is rumoured to sport a 6.7-inch display with a refresh rate of 120Hz and an in-buit fingerprint sensor. Under the hood, the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 chipset is rumoured to be paired with up to 12GB of RAM and up to 512GB of internal storage.

In terms of camera, the company claims that the Realme GT 2 Pro is the first smartphone to offer a 150-degrees ultra-wide camera, which expands the phone's field of view by 278% compared to the main camera's 84-degrees field. The company has also developed the world's first fisheye mode for smartphones on the device to provide an ultra-long depth of field effect.

The device is also equipped with HyperSmart antenna switching technology that is designed with 12 wrap-around antennas that cover all sides of the phone and support mainstream bands in almost all directions, all with the same signal strength. This allows GT 2 Pro to evaluate the signal strength of all antennas and automatically select the one with the best signal.

column9: [Exclusive] Possible OnePlus 10 With Dimensity 9000 in the Works, May Enter Testing Soon in Global Markets - MySmartPrice
column10:
OnePlus is gearing up for the OnePlus 10 series launch in China. The company will officially announce the launch date on January 4. A leaked video suggests that the flagship smartphone series from OnePlus will debut in China on January 11. While we wait for the official confirmation, rumours suggest that the company will only launch the OnePlus 10 Pro in January. The vanilla model will launch sometime later this year. OnePlus is yet to confirm the rumour. Meanwhile, MySmartPrice has exclusively learned that the Oppo sub-brand is working on a smartphone with a MediaTek Dimensity 9000 SoC. As per our source Yogesh Brar, this device could well be the OnePlus 10.

MediaTek unveiled the Dimensity 9000 SoC late last year. It said that devices with the new flagship processor will debut starting February. The chipset comes with a 1+3+4 cluster and is based on a 4nm process. It has a peak clock speed of 3.0GHz with three performance cores clocked at 2.85GHz and four efficiency cores clocked at 1.79GHz. The upcoming vanilla OnePlus 10 could get the MediaTek processor while the Pro model will feature Qualcomm's Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC.

OnePlus has not confirmed any details regarding the vanilla model at the moment. If the latest rumours are to be believed, the standard OnePlus 10 will get a launch date sometime around mid-2022. The device could replace the OnePlus 10R, which is unlikely to get a refresh this year due to the OnePlus 9RT launching later this month in India.

The tipster further tells us that OnePlus will soon start testing the devices with its new unified OS with Oppo for the global markets. Considering that the unified OS will launch later this year, we can expect the devices to boot with Android 12-based ColorOS 12/ Oxygen OS 12 out of the box. Meanwhile, you can click here to know more about the Pro model's leaked specs and design details ahead of the launch.

column9: Best smartphones under Rs 30,000 in January 2022: OnePlus Nord 2, Mi 11X top picks in new year
column10:
There are several options in sub-Rs 30,000 price point.Mi 11X remains to be the Best Buy at this point.OnePlus Nord 2 is a great all-rounder as well.

We have entered a new year and soon, the smartphone market will be flooded with several new options. It's no surprise that the first week itself will see at least two new mid-premium smartphones in India - Vivo V23 Pro and Xiaomi 11i HyperCharge. The Vivo phone is launching on January 5 while Xiaomi will unveil its first smartphone of the year the very next day. Both these smartphones are likely to be priced around Rs 30,000. So, this is probably the best time to re-visit the best options available in the market right now.

Xiaomi's Mi 11X was one of the best smartphones to launch under Rs 30,000 last year and remains to be one of our top recommendations in January 2022. Similarly, OnePlus Nord 2 is a great all-rounder at this price, offering something in nearly all departments. Other smartphones in this price category also come with good, high-refresh displays, decent cameras and fast charging tech.

Most of these smartphones also support 5G connectivity now. In case you are planning to upgrade the phone, here are the best smartphones under Rs 30,000 in India right now.

Mi 11X

As mentioned before, Mi 11X was probably the best mid-range smartphone to launch in India in 2021. The smartphone comes with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 870 processor. It features a 6.67-inch AMOLED Full-HD+ display with a 120Hz refresh rate. The handset packs a 4520mAh battery with 33W fast charging support.

It sports a 48-megapixel primary camera, an 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera, and a 5-megapixel telemacro camera. The Mi 11X is available in India at a starting price of Rs 27,999 for the 6GB RAM model and goes up to Rs 29,999 for the 8GB RAM option.

Our verdict - The Mi 11X has three things that go in its favour, including good performance, excellent display, and decent battery life. However, the poor cameras and average speaker performance are big issues.

Read our full review here

OnePlus Nord 2

The first OnePlus Nord phone revived the mid-premium category and Nord 2 has only taken the legacy ahead. The phone is powered by MediaTek Dimensity 1200-AI and runs on Android 11-based OxygenOS 11.3. It is an excellent all-rounder with a 6.43-inch AMOLED display with 1080x2400 pixels screen resolution with a 20:9 aspect ratio.

The Nord 2 sports a 50-megapixel Sony IMX766 primary camera, an 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera, and a 2-megapixel mono camera. The handset also packs a 32-megapixel selfie camera. The smartphone packs a 4500mAh battery and comes with Warp Charge 65 support.

The price in India starts at Rs 27,999 for the 6GB RAM model, while the 8GB comes at Rs 29,999.

Our verdict - The OnePlus Nord 2 is a great all-rounder device and packs a fantastic processor for gaming. The handset offers an excellent premium feel and gives a solid battery life.

Read our full review here

Poco F3 GT

Next on the list is a phone which isn't talked about as much as it should be - Poco F3 GT. The smartphone was launched amid a lot of hype and targeted young gamers at a tight budget. It features a MediaTek Dimensity 1200 processor, has a 120Hz AMOLED display and comes with Maglev triggers on the side panel for gaming.

It packs a massive 5065mAh battery with 67W fast charging support. The Poco F3 GT supports 5G and offers dual stereo speakers with Dolby Atmos. The handset features a 64-megapixel primary camera, an 8-megapixel ultra-wide camera, and a 2-megapixel macro camera. The Poco F3 GT also sports a side-mounted fingerprint scanner. The smartphone is available in India at Rs 28,999.

Our verdict - The three things we liked about the Poco F3 GT are its premium design, responsive triggers that come in handy while gaming, and excellent battery performance. We would have loved it if the camera performed slightly better, while 3.5mm audio jack lovers would hate not finding it.

Read our full review here

Moto Edge 20

Motorola has been doing well lately. It has started pricing the phones really well. The Moto Edge 20 comes with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 778G processor. It packs 128GB of storage and comes with 8GB of RAM. The smartphone comes with a side-mounted fingerprint reader.

Moto Edge 20 packs a eatures a 6.7-inch AMOLED Full-HD+ display with a 20:9 aspect ratio. The smartphone supports a 144Hz refresh rate. The handset also comes with IP52 certification for water resistance. The smartphone's biggest highlight is its 108-megapixel primary camera at the back. It comes with 5G support. The Moto Edge 20 is available in India at Rs 29,999.

Our verdict - The Moto Edge 20 sports a flat-edge design that works well for the device. The three big highlights of the device are its display, performance, and balanced design. The camera, however, could have been better, and the missing headphone jack may not be liked by many.

Read our full review here

column9: Xiaomi 12 Series Global, India launch tipped - The Mobile Indian
column10:
Xiaomi recently unveiled its 12 series smartphones comprising of three smartPhones including Xiaomi 12, 12X and 12 Pro. Two of these three were powered by Qualcomm's latest Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC. Now, the India and Global launch of the Xiaomi 12 series has been tipped.

The report comes from MySmartPrice in collaboration with tipster Mukul Sharma. The tipster has informed the publication that the Xiaomi 12 series smartphones will launch outside China by February end or early March. Furthermore, Xiaomi could also launch its 12 series smartphones in India soon after the global launch, if not around the same time. But, unfortunately, there's no exact launch date as of now.

The leader of the pack is the Xiaomi 12 Pro. The device sports a 6.73-inch AMOLED LTPO (Samsung E5) display with a QHD+ (3200 x 1440 pixels) resolution, a 120Hz refresh rate, a 480Hz touch sampling rate, and a 100% touch sampling rate DCI-P3 wide colour gamut coverage. Along with that, it has Dolby Vision and HDR10+ support with 1500nits of peak brightness and Corning Gorilla Glass Victus protection.

The device is powered by the Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC and up to 12GB of LPDDR5 RAM and up to 256GB of UFS 3.1 storage. The Adreno 730 GPU handles the graphics. At the rear, you get a triple camera setup, including a 50MP IMX707 main camera with OIS, a 50MP ultrawide camera and a 50MP telephoto sensor. At the front, there's a 32MP sensor for selfies.

The Xiaomi 12 Pro is backed by a 4600mAh battery that supports 120W fast charging and is also equipped with Xiaomi's own Surge P1 charging chip. Further, there's support for 50W fast wireless charging and 10W reverse wireless charging. Connectivity options include 5G NR, NFC, Wi-Fi 6, Bluetooth 5.2 and USB Type C. Additional features include four-unit stereo speakers tuned by Harman Kardon, which has 2x woofers and 2x tweeters. The device runs on Android 12 based on MIUI 13.

column9: The 2nd-gen AirPods Pro's killer feature could be lossless audio
column10:
Apple is rumored to deliver high-quality audio to its Bluetooth earbuds.

body>

One of the most anticipated Apple products of 2022 is the second-generation AirPods Pro, which is expected to bring a new design to the iconic high-end earbuds. But a new report by Ming-Chi Kuo (via 9to5Mac) claims that Apple might have an even more exciting trick up its sleeve.

Kuo says Apple's next-generation AirPods, which are due to arrive in the fourth quarter of 2022, will add support for the Apple Lossless (ALAC) format in Apple Music that began rolling out in June, making them the first pair of AirPods and one of the only true wireless earbuds to support the higher-quality format. Apple previously brought lossless support to the HomePod with the launch of iOS 15.1 but has been unable to deliver lossless for AirPods due to the bandwidth limitations of Bluetooth.

Delivering lossless audio to the AirPods Pro would require technology able to increase the available bandwidth for streaming. Qualcomm's aptX Adaptive, which was announced in September, stitches together two proprietary technologies to increase the data throughput required to handle lossless' 44.1kHz, 1,411 kbps bitrate:

To help deliver CD lossless audio quality reliably over Bluetooth wireless technology, aptX Adaptive works in conjunction with Qualcomm Bluetooth High Speed Link technology to help deliver the required sustainable data throughput. Designed to work seamlessly together, these technologies deliver rates beyond 1Mbit/s yet smoothly scale down to 140kbits/s in congested RF environments to minimize any audio dropouts or glitches for a consistent and reliable listening experience.

Apple will likely do something similar for the AirPods Pro. In an interview with What Hi-Fi, VP of Acoustics Gary Geaves said there's a number of tricks we can play to maximize or get around some of the limits of Bluetooth.

Bringing lossless audio to the AirPods Pro would be one more reason to buy a pair over the cheaper third-gen AirPods, along with noise cancellation and Conversation Boost.

column9: Consistent Sales And Margin Growth Makes Thermo Fisher Scientific Stock Attractive
column10:
We think that Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. currently is a better pick compared to Qualcomm Inc.. Both companies have their current P/S multiples around 6x, while TMO's current P/EBIT stands marginally higher at 23x. Do these valuations make sense? We don't think so, and we believe TMO should be valued higher. While both companies have seen a strong rise in revenues since the lockdowns started being lifted, TMO has seen much more rapid and consistent sales growth over the past five fiscal years than Qualcomm. TMO's revenues have risen from $18.3 billion in FY '16 to $32.2 billion in FY '20 and currently stand at a strong $39.1 billion on an LTM basis. In comparison, Qualcomm's sales hovered around the $23 billion mark between FY '16 and FY '20, before surging to $33 billion in FY '21 (Qualcomm's fiscal year ends in September).

Having said that, we dive deeper into the comparison, which makes Thermo Fisher Scientific a better bet than Qualcomm, even at these valuations. Let's step back to look at the fuller picture of the relative valuation of the two companies by looking at detailed historical revenue growth as well as operating income and operating margin growth, along with the financial position. Our dashboard Qualcomm vs Thermo Fisher Scientific: Similar Income, But Thermo Fisher Scientific Is A Better Bet has more details on this. Parts of the analysis are summarized below.

1. Thermo Fisher Scientific Ahead On Revenue Growth

Both companies managed to see strong sales growth post the pandemic, but TMO has witnessed much faster and more consistent revenue growth over the years. TMO's sales have jumped from $18.3 billion in FY '16 to $39.1 billion on an LTM basis, while Qualcomm's revenues have risen from $23.6 billion in FY '16 to around $33 billion on an LTM basis.

Further, TMO's pre-Covid annual sales growth stands at 11.2%, higher than Qualcomm's 1.4%, and even growth during Covid stands at 26.1%, higher than Qualcomm's -3.1%. However, for the most recent quarter, Qualcomm saw more than 60% sales growth YoY, much more than TMO's 9.5%. Even on an LTM basis, Qualcomm's sales growth stands at 62.9%, more than TMO's 37.1%.

Having said that, TMO's sales growth over the years has been much more consistent compared to Qualcomm, and we believe this should be rewarded in the form of a higher valuation for TMO.

2. Qualcomm Ahead On EBIT Margins, But Thermo Fisher Scientific In A Better Cash Position

Qualcomm's P/EBIT ratio stands at around 22x currently, marginally lower than TMO's 23x. This is a little harsh since Qualcomm's LTM EBIT margins stand at 31.7%, higher than TMO's 27%. Further, in terms of recent margin growth, Qualcomm stands ahead, with LTM vs last three FY margin change at 11.4%, more than TMO's 7.8%.

Now, looking at both companies' cash position, TMO's debt as a % of equity stands at 0%, vs Qualcomm's 1%. However, TMO's cash as a % of assets stands much higher at 33.3%, compared to Qualcomm's 16.3%.

3. Finally, Thermo Fisher Scientific Is Ahead In Terms Of Expected Returns

Using P/S as a base, due to high fluctuations in P/E and P/EBIT, we believe TMO is the better choice. TMO's LTM revenues of $39 billion are expected to rise at a CAGR of 11.3% as per our estimates, taking revenue numbers three years out to as high as $54 billion. Assuming TMO's P/S ratio to pull back to an average of about 5.6x, this means that the market cap would rise to $302 billion, an upside of 19% over three years.

In comparison, given historical trends, we expect Qualcomm's sales to rise slower at a CAGR of just 1.6%, taking revenue in three years to a little over $34 billion. However, considering the P/S for Qualcomm to correct to historical averages of around 5x, we estimate a market cap of $175 billion for QCOM, much lower than the level it is at today.

The Net of It All

TMO's revenues are larger than that of Qualcomm's, and the former has also seen faster and more consistent revenue growth over the years, combined with strong EBIT margins and a better cash position. Additionally, our comparison of the post-Covid recovery above, shows that TMO has seen steadier growth than Qualcomm. Due to this, we believe that TMO deserves a higher P/S and P/EBIT multiple compared to Qualcomm, and we believe that this will reflect in the companies' relative valuations soon. As such, we believe that Thermo Fisher Scientific stock is currently a better bet compared to Qualcomm stock.

What if you're looking for a more balanced portfolio instead? Here's a high-quality portfolio that's beaten the market consistently since the end of 2016.

column10:
Apple is rumored to deliver high-quality audio to its Bluetooth earbuds.

body>

column9: Tronsmart Onyx Prime Dual-Driver Wireless Earbuds
column10:
These reasonably priced earbuds serve up crisp audio and great connectivity, albeit with quite a basic appearance.

Over the past few years, the earbud market has expanded significantly, with a lot of the top technology brands all serving up their own take on the hardware. While a lot of these devices come with a premium price tag, there are cheaper alternatives, alternatives that deliver a device with top-notch qualities without requiring you to shell out a bigger sum of cash. This is precisely what Tronsmart has brought to the table with its Onyx Prime Dual-Driver Wireless Earbuds, a gadget that presents quality and ease of use, albeit with quite a basic appearance. I've been testing these earbuds for a little while now and have some thoughts about them and whether or not you should be looking to grab a pair.

Coming as part of a neatly packaged and folding box, the Onyx Prime comes as part of a parcel that also includes a manual, various different sized silicone tips and pieces, and a USB 2.0 to USB-C charging cable. There's not a whole to really delve into here, aside from the fact that the silicone pieces come in four different sizes so that you choose the perfect one to fit the shape and size of your ears, which is always a plus.

As for the actual Onyx Prime system, this is split into three parts: the case, the left earbud and the right earbud. The case is a pretty typical size for wireless earbuds, measuring 70mm by 48.3mm by 30.4mm, and comes in a rounded off rectangular shape in purely black, bar a tiny LED light that graces the rear of the case just above the charging port, and serves as a charging and battery indicator. When you flip open the lid, which seems to be marginally magnetised to ensure a secure fit, you'll find that both earbuds take up the majority of the body, except for where they rest over the bottom centre of the case, where the charging cable connects.

As for each earbud, alike the case, these come in pure black as well, except for having a grey Tronsmart logo on its side, and a LED light just below that flashes when you use the various touch commands it offers. In terms of their appearance, there's really not a lot to say. These are around 35mm long and 15mm wide, and aside from the minimalist and blocky design, the only other part that stands out is the arching silicone piece that fits just a little behind the actual silicone tip, with the purpose to better fit the shape of your ears and hold the earbud in place more firmly. Personally, I'm not a huge fan of the look this silicone piece gives the earbud, but considering removing them leaves an indented space on the earbud, I found it better to leave them on.

While they aren't the most eye-catching or exciting looking earbuds, the Onyx Prime does make up for this by delivering clear and high-quality audio, regardless of whether you're listening to chaotic rock or bassy electronic music, or even simply just streaming a movie or playing a game. These earbuds display a broad and deep audio range, and this remains true even when you crank the volume up significantly, which is a situation where a lot of earbuds commonly begin to show distortion and a drop in quality.

The reason why this isn't the case with the Onyx Prime is down to the Qualcomm QCC3040 chip and the hybrid Dual-Driver technology that combine to create a device with a wider frequency range capable of delivering a greater and clearer audio profile. Match this up with Bluetooth 5.2 technology and Tronsmart's TrueWireless systems, and you get audio and a device that is both clear and defined, but also lag-free and capable of serving this up even at ranges that are over 10m away from your actual phone or whatever you are connected to.

In terms of the fit of the actual earbuds, I've found this to be a little all over the place. Even after switching out the various silicone extra parts, my right earbud fits comfortably and firmly and with a solid seal, which helps serve up a better listening experience, but my left earbud, despite a lot of trial and error, always seems to lack the same seal, making for a fit that often feels like its about to fall out - even though it never actually does. I haven't ruled out my ears being the problem here, but considering this is an issue I've not encountered with other earbuds, it seems to be related to the Onyx Prime first and foremost.

As for how the earbuds feel while wearing, they are light and barely noticeable, and thanks to the use of silicone tips, you don't get the same level of lack of comfort after hours of use, as first generation Airpods often served up, as an example.

Building on using the Onyx Prime for hours, from my experience with these earbuds, I can add that you'll never really have an issue with battery or charge. The buds are expected to last for seven hours on a single charge, with the case and its extra charge adding an extra 33 hours to that total, assuming you are playing music at around 50% volume for that duration. If you prefer a louder listening experience, like me, you'll still get plenty out of this system, but it won't be the promised full 40 hours, before needing to charge it back - which only takes a couple of hours to fully do so as well.

As a final couple of points, I'd like to mention just how easy the Onyx Prime is to set up and connect to your device, and how the touch controls work. Connecting simply requires you to lift the lid on the case with the buds inside, and then selecting the Onyx Prime from your phone/tablet's Bluetooth available connection list and then you're off. It's really that simple.

Looking at the touch controls, these are pretty basic and allow you to skip songs, adjust volume, answer calls, power on/off, and more. The idea is to tap where the logo is on the side of the earbuds, and for the most part, this works effectively and fluidly. It's not perfect and there are times where you'll be doing an action a couple of times before it clocks it, or rather you'll try doing one thing and it'll do something else instead, but this seems to be fairly typical for earbud touch controls in general, in my experience.

All In all though, considering the Onyx Prime is quite a cheap set of earbuds, retailing for around £45-55, there's not a lot to dislike about them. The audio is surprisingly clear and high-quality for a system on the cheaper side of the spectrum, and the ease of use and connectivity only serves to elevate the experience. Granted, they don't really have the most eye-catching or exciting appearance, but that's hardly a reason to not grab a pair if you're looking for some capable earbuds for a reasonable price, as the Onyx Prime ticks all of those boxes.

column9: Opinion | Stocks to watch in 2022
column10:
"If you aren't willing to own a stock for 10 years, don't even think about owning it for ten minutes." -- Warren Buffett

The year ahead is one of recovery -- from pandemic restrictions, labour shortages and supply-chain disruptions.

But while the stocks highlighted here should do well in 2022, they are also expected to reward investors long after the pandemic economic recovery. They are not glamour stocks but reliable performers with characteristics of both income and growth stocks.

These firms are each sufficiently dominant in their fields, and consistently well managed, that investors can rely on them for modest capital gains and respectable dividend income for many years to come.

Buffett once allowed that his ideal period for owning a stock was "forever." Day traders can stop reading here. These stocks are intended as keepers.

Restaurant Brands International Inc. RBI, owner of the Tim Hortons, Burger King and Popeyes restaurant brands, has an ambitious goal to increase its total store count by about 50 per cent, to some 40,000 locations, by 2030.

RBI has shown its ability to execute on such challenges with its recent turnarounds at Tim Hortons and Burger King, its two biggest brands. Their same-store sales growth in the latest quarter jumped 8.9 per cent and 7.9 per cent, respectively.

Tim Hortons is "tripling down" on espresso, a growth opportunity it acknowledges having long neglected. It is also upgrading its lunch and dinner offerings. They currently amount to only 35 per cent of Tim Horton's sales, in a segment that accounts for 60 per cent of the fast-food industry.

RBI's November acquisition of Florida-based Firehouse Restaurant Group Inc. for $1 billion (U.S.) gives RBI further growth potential. With forecast 2021 sales of $1.1 billion (U.S.), the fast-growing Firehouse Subs chain, with about 1,200 stores, still has only a fraction of the estimated $30 billion (U.S.) fast-food sandwich market.

RBI stock is trading about 40 per cent below its 2019 peak of about $75 (Cdn.). And the shares boast a handsome dividend yield of 3.6 per cent.

What makes RBI interesting as a long-term investment is its industry-leading tech platform, to which new stores and entire chains can be added with relative ease.

And RBI benefits from one of the industry's biggest franchisee networks. RBI is counting on its franchisees to expand the Firehouse brand in Canada, where it now has just 50 locations; and the Tim Hortons brand in China, where RBI is planning for hundreds of new stores.

Rogers Communications Inc. The high-profile dispute over control of Rogers last fall obscures the company's underlying strengths. So do pandemic economics.

As Canada's largest wireless provider, Toronto-based Rogers has taken a bigger hit than rivals BCE Inc. and Telus Corp. in sharply reduced roaming charges. Those are the fees that wireless customers pay when using their devices abroad.

That, of course, is part of the upside story at Rogers. At this writing, all bets are off on the impact of the Omicron variant of the coronavirus. But travel restrictions will eventually be lifted, and pre-pandemic levels of roaming revenues will be restored.

The big bet for Rogers' investors is the firm's ability to win regulatory approval for its proposed $26-billion acquisition of rival Shaw Communications Inc., which won't come before the end of the year.

Most analysts expect deal approval, though many believe Shaw's Freedom Mobile unit will have to be excluded to maintain sufficient competition.

With Shaw, Rogers would be able to spread its cost of upgrading to 5G, or fifth-generation wireless, over a bigger customer base. And the combined firm would have greater marketing heft in luring subscribers away from Bell and Telus.

Rogers outpaced Bell and Telus in pre-pandemic profit growth, more than doubling profit in the four years to 2019.

Shares in the company trade 13 per cent below their 2019 peak of about $73. They pay a rich dividend yield of 3.2 per cent. And they're the cheapest of the Big Three telecoms, trading at a multiple of 20 times earnings. The p/e's for BCE and Telus are 21.2 and 30.8, respectively.

Enbridge Inc. Enbridge is a reliable income stock. Its 6.7 per cent dividend is one of the richest in Corporate Canada. But Enbridge also has growth prospects unusual for utilities.

The Calgary-based company operates the world's longest network of oil and gas pipelines, with more than 28,000 kilometres of pipe in active use.

A return to normal rates of North American fuel consumption alone should restore Enbridge's sales to their 2019 level, a 40 per cent increase over 2020.

Because of its sprawling pipeline network across North America, Enbridge is ideally suited to continually purchasing still more pipelines for integration into its network.

That advantage helped Enbridge more than double its profits in the four pre-pandemic years ending in 2019.

And as one of Canada's largest renewable energy firms, Enbridge is also an investor hedge against the expected gradual decline in fossil fuel use and the ascendancy of alternative energy sources.

Enbridge operates or has large equity stakes in 23 wind farms and 11 solar energy operations in Canada, the U.S., and Europe. Combined, Enbridge's share of these projects generates 2.1 megawatts (MW) of electricity, equivalent to the power demands of about 945,000 homes.

The firm's renewable energy portfolio also includes a hydroelectric power plant, a geothermal project, and several waste heat recovery facilities.

Enbridge has so far invested more than $7 billion in renewable energy projects. Enbridge has the cash flow to further increase its renewable energy commitment as the North American energy mix changes.

In the meantime, the stock trades at a reasonable multiple of 17.5 times earnings. At a current price of $48, its shares are 21 per cent below Enbridge's 2017 peak price of about $61.05.

Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd. CP's proposed $34.6 -billion merger with Kansas City Southern, formalized in September, would enable CP to apply its best-in-class operating efficiencies across a much larger customer base.

CP expects that the rechristened CPKC, which would remain headquartered in Calgary, would be more competitive in wooing shippers away from less fuel-efficient truck transport, the chief rival to rail.

And CPKC would provide shippers with access to Atlantic, Pacific and Gulf of Mexico ports unmatched by its five Class 1 railway peers in North America.

The combination would boost CP revenues by more than 40 per cent, to about $11 billion. And it would expand CP's rail network by about 25 per cent, to more than 32,000 km. of track.

The proposed CPKC would be the only Class 1 railway with an extensive rail network in Mexico.

The short-term issue hanging over the stock is whether that transformational deal will win approval from a U.S. rail regulator that more than once has rejected Canada-U.S. rail mergers.

But odds are that Mexican regulatory approval for the deal in November foreshadows a favourable decision by the U.S. Surface Transportation Board (STB). The proposed merger has been painstakingly structured to earn the STB's approval in a decision expected next spring.

In the meantime, CP has been an outstanding performer, with profits that have increased by 50 per cent in the past five years. CP stock value has room to grow, having recovered by more than 72 per cent from its 2020 low, but less than the 94 per cent average for its Class 1 peers. CP shares are also the lowest priced among that group, trading at just 19 times earnings.

Magna International Inc. Magna expects that its heavy investment in electric vehicles (EVs) will pay off in a total revenue increase of at least 25 per cent by 2023, to about $55 billion in annual sales.

In aggressively bulking up its EV capability, Magna is partnering with global firms including South Korean components maker LG Electronics Inc., Israeli EV tech start-up REE Automotive, and California EV designer Fisker Inc.

As one of the world's few contract automakers, Magna, based in Aurora, Ont., will build the first line of all-electric Fisker Ocean SUVs at its Austrian assembly plant starting in November 2022.

Global rivalry to snap up specialized makers of auto equipment is intense. In October, Magna was outbid for Veoneer Inc., a Swedish company focused on auto safety tech.

That Magna had $4.9 billion to finance that purchase speaks to the strength of its balance sheet. And its refusal to top a 20 per cent higher competing bid by Qualcomm Inc. is a reassurance of Magna's discipline during a buying spree in which both traditional automakers and Silicon Valley firms are bidding up auto-related assets.

Meanwhile, Magna's internal R&D powerhouse and its swelling roster of outside tech alliances enables it to offer its long-standing automaker customers a growing portfolio of EV engines, powertrain systems and safety components.

Magna shares are trading about 19 per below their June peak of $125.24, due to short-term supply chain problems afflicting Magna's customers. The stock is reasonably priced, trading at less than 13 times earnings, and its dividend yield is a respectable 2.1 per cent.

column9: Xiaomi 12 Series Global Launch Timeline Tipped: Ultra Variant Likely On Cards
column10:
Xiaomi announced the launch of its latest flagship smartphones in the Xiaomi 12 series. The company unveiled three models - the standard Xiaomi 12, the premium 12 Pro and the affordable 12X models. Already, these devices are official in China and the global markets including India are awaiting their launch.

While there is no official confirmation regarding the global launch of the Xiaomi 12 series, a report has revealed the possible launch timeline of these models in India. This information was shared by MySmartPrice citing the tipster Mukul Sharma.

As per the claim, the Xiaomi 12 smartphones will be launched outside of China by the end of February or early March. The India launch of these smartphones will follow the global launch, if not at the same time. However, it remains to be seen when exactly the India launch of these smartphones will take place.

Xiaomi 12 bestows a 6.28-inch FHD+ AMOLED display with Corning Gorilla Glass Victus protection and a 120Hz refresh rate. Also, it has Dolby Vision support. Under its hood, the Xiaomi 12 uses an octa-core Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC.

It flaunts a triple-camera setup at the rear with a 50MP primary Sony IMX766 sensor with an f/1.88 lens and optical image stabilization (OIS) support. It houses a 13MP secondary ultra-wide lens and a 5MP tertiary macro lens. This camera uses the proprietary CyberFocus technology for an enhanced focus. At the front, there is a 32MP selfie camera sensor with support for Stagger HDR and AI beautification.

Connectivity aspects include 5G, 4G LTE, Wi-Fi 6E, Bluetooth v5.2, GPS, NFC, Infrared and a USB Type-C port. Xiaomi 12 features Dolby Atmos support, Harman Kardon-tuned stereo speakers and HiRes audio. A 4500mAh battery with 67W fast charging and 50W wireless charging fuels the device. It has 10W reverse wireless charging as well.

Xiaomi 12 Pro adorns a 6.73-inch WQHD+ E5 AMOLED display with a 120Hz dynamic refresh rate and Corning Gorilla Glass Victus protection. There is a low-temperature polycrystalline oxide (LTPO) backplane technology used by Apple on premium iPhones. The processor is the same as seen on the standard variant.

While the connectivity and storage aspects are also the same, the Xiaomi 12 Pro houses a triple-camera setup with three 50MP sensors. It comes with a four-unit speaker system including a dedicated tweeter and Harman Kardon tuning support. A 4600mAh battery fuels the Pro variant with 120W fast wired charging. Also, there is 50W wireless charging and 10W reverse wireless charging support.

The Xiaomi 12X is a modified version of the Xiaomi 12. It comes with the same 6.28-inch display, camera setup and battery. However, it uses an octa-core Qualcomm Snapdragon 870 SoC.

Besides these smartphones, Xiaomi 12 Ultra is speculated to be on cards and could be unveiled in February. This ultra-premium flagship is yet to be officially confirmed and could see the light of the day after the Chinese Spring festival. The Ultra variant is expected to feature a quad-camera setup with a 50MP primary camera and three 48MP shooters serving as the ultrawide, 3x telephoto zoom and 10X zoom lenses respectively.

column9: OnePlus 10 Pro launching this month: Launch date, specs, price, and other details you need to know
column10:
From the launch date, specifications, price and all other details about the upcoming OnePlus 10 Pro. Take a detailed look.

OnePlus has been working on the OnePlus 10 series for the past several months now. Under the smartphone series, the company is expected to launch two models - the OnePlus 10 and the OnePlus 10 Pro. Also Read - OnePlus 10 Pro likely to launch next week: Specs, features, price, everything we know so far

Ahead of the release, a lot has been revealed about the Pro model. So, here let's take a look at everything that rumours and leaks have revealed about the OnePlus 10 Pro so far. From the launch date, specifications, price, and all other details. Also Read - Smartphones confirmed to launch in January 2022: OnePlus 10 Pro, Realme GT 2 series, and more

OnePlus 10 Pro launch date

The company is officially expected to reveal the launch date of the OnePlus 10 series in China tomorrow on January 4. However, if we go by rumours and leaks, both the phones are likely to release on January 11. It should be noted that the company will launch the phones in China first and later followed by the global market including India. Currently, the latest rumours suggest that India will get the OnePlus 9RT next, which was released in China nearly 3 months back. Also Read - OnePlus 10 Pro is expected to come with support for up to 80W fast charging

OnePlus 10 Pro specifications

Rumours and leaks circulating on the internet have revealed almost all the crucial details about the upcoming OnePlus 10 Pro. Let's take a look at the leaked specifications:

-The OnePlus 10 Pro comes packed with a 6.7-inch AMOLED display with a 2K resolution. The phone is expected to offer a refresh rate of 120Hz.

-It is said to be powered by the latest Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 SoC paired with up to 12GB of RAM and 256GB of internal storage.

-Some rumours suggest that the smartphone will come packed with a 5,000mAh battery with support for 80W wired and 50W wireless fast charging.

-On the camera front, the OnePlus 10 Pro will come packed with a 48-megapixel primary camera bundled with a 50-megapixel ultra-wide-angle camera and an 8-megapixel telephoto lens. On the front, the phone is likely to include a 32-megapixel camera for selfies and video calls.

-Some of the other features are likely to include dual nano SIMs, USB Type-C audio, Dual Stereo speakers, Dolby Atmos, a fingerprint sensor, LPDDR5 RAM and UFS 3.1 storage.

-OnePlus 10 Pro is expected to be the first smartphone to come with a unified operating system based on Android 12.

OnePlus 10 Pro price

While the company hasn't revealed the pricing details yet, but it is likely that the OnePlus 10 Pro will be priced somewhere around Rs 60,000. This is also the first OnePlus smartphone to include the latest Snapdragon flagship processor. With the device, the Chinese smartphone manufacturer will take on the likes of the Xiaomi 12 and the iPhone 13 Pro Max.

Currently, there are no details around the India launch of the OnePlus 10 Pro yet.

column9: The 2nd-gen AirPods Pro's killer feature could be lossless audio
column10:
Apple is rumored to deliver high-quality audio to its Bluetooth earbuds.

One of the most anticipated Apple products of 2022 is the second-generation AirPods Pro, which is expected to bring a new design to the iconic high-end earbuds. But a new report by Ming-Chi Kuo (via 9to5Mac) claims that Apple might have an even more exciting trick up its sleeve.

Kuo says Apple's next-generation AirPods, which are due to arrive in the fourth quarter of 2022, will add support for the Apple Lossless (ALAC) format in Apple Music that began rolling out in June, making them the first pair of AirPods and one of the only true wireless earbuds to support the higher-quality format. Apple previously brought lossless support to the HomePod with the launch of iOS 15.1 but has been unable to deliver lossless for AirPods due to the bandwidth limitations of Bluetooth.

Delivering lossless audio to the AirPods Pro would require technology able to increase the available bandwidth for streaming. Qualcomm's aptX Adaptive, which was announced in September, stitches together two proprietary technologies to increase the data throughput required to handle lossless' 44.1kHz, 1,411 kbps bitrate:

"To help deliver CD lossless audio quality reliably over Bluetooth wireless technology, aptX Adaptive works in conjunction with Qualcomm Bluetooth High Speed Link technology to help deliver the required sustainable data throughput. Designed to work seamlessly together, these technologies deliver rates beyond 1Mbit/s yet smoothly scale down to 140kbits/s in congested RF environments to minimize any audio dropouts or glitches for a consistent and reliable listening experience."

Apple will likely do something similar for the AirPods Pro. In an interview with What Hi-Fi, VP of Acoustics Gary Geaves said "there's a number of tricks we can play to maximize or get around some of the limits of Bluetooth."

Bringing lossless audio to the AirPods Pro would be one more reason to buy a pair over the cheaper third-gen AirPods, along with noise cancellation and Conversation Boost.

column9: Best gaming mobile phones under 15000 in January 2022 include Realme Narzo 50A, Moto G51 5G
column10:
These phones are good for playing BGMI, PUBG New State, and Call of Duty Mobile.

New year should not be just about the resolutions that many of you know will abandon in a few days. It should also be about shopping and if you are looking for a gaming phone on budget, you have come to the right place. Now, you have at least four battle royale games, Battlegrounds Mobile India, PUBG: New State, Call of Duty Mobile, and Garena Free Fire, that you can play, but your experience will not be pleasant unless your phone is not good in specifications and features. The good thing is that you do not have to spend a bomb on such a phone.

At India Today Tech, we come across all sorts of smartphones and they belong to different price segments. If you are looking for a gaming phone for under Rs 15,000, you have many options. But we have handpicked only a few ones that we have thoroughly tested. These phones come from different brands but they are all going to give you an enjoyable gaming experience. We have included phones in this list according to their current prices on online shopping websites.

Realme Narzo 50A

Realme's Narzo series of smartphones has mostly been about big specifications at a small price. The company touts that this series is meant for youngsters, who like to play a lot of games. And the Narzo 50A is no exception. The phone has a MediaTek Helio G85 processor, which is good enough to handle modest gaming. It has a 6.5-inch HD+ display, which is a big size, so you will not have issues firing that gun. The Realme Narzo 50A starts at Rs 11,499 and it is available on Flipkart, Amazon, and Realme's online store.

Our verdict: The Realme Narzo 50A is a good phone for its price. And it ticks most of the right boxes. Big display? Check. Good processor? Check. Long-lasting battery? Check. All of that is reasonable enough to make the Narzo 50A a compelling option on the market. And for Rs 11,499, I think it is the right investment.

Motorola Moto G51 5G

Motorola recently expanded its 5G lineup with the addition of G51 5G. This phone takes inspiration from the Motorola Moto G 5G. The best part about this phone is the stock Android software that makes it easy to navigate the interface. The Moto G51 5G comes with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 480 Pro processor, which is slightly better than the vanilla version and that means better gaming performance. The Motorola Moto G51 5G sells for Rs 14,999 on Flipkart.

Our verdict: The Moto G51 5G's display is pretty vibrant, the apps also loaded quickly and there weren't any visible lags. The phone comes with near-stock Android, so you won't have to endure bloatware and the annoying notifications from the pre-loaded apps. Overall, the phone has a very clean interface with no unwanted apps.

Redmi Note 10T 5G

The Redmi Note 10T 5G was launched as another variant in the Redmi Note series and its specifications make the phone good enough for gaming. It costs Rs Rs 14,999 for the entry-level model and we liked the phone for what it brings for that price. The Redmi Note 10T 5G comes with a 6.5-inch full-HD+ display with up to a 90Hz refresh rate and a 20:9 aspect ratio, MediaTek Dimensity 700 SoC with up to 6GB RAM, and a 5000mAh battery that will help you have the Chicken Dinner.

Our verdict: It was about time that Xiaomi had added an affordable 5G smartphone to its portfolio, given that most of its devices till Rs 25,000 (except Mi 10i) only support 4G networks, while the competition has shifted its strategy to 5G. The Redmi Note 10T 5G solves that purpose by offering an option under Rs 15,000.

Poco M3 Pro 5G

The Poco M3 Pro 5G is also a phone that we would recommend to gamers who are on a budget. The Poco M3 Pro 5G sports a 6.55-inch Full-HD+ display with a 90Hz refresh rate. It is powered by an octa-core Mediatek Dimesity 700 SoC with up to 6GB of RAM and 128GB of storage. A 48-megapixel triple rear camera setup and an 8-megapixel sensor for selfies are there, too. The Poco M3 Pro 5G is powered by a 5000mAh battery with support for 18W fast charging. The Poco M3 Pro 5G starts at Rs 14,499.

Our verdict: The Poco M3 Pro 5G offers suitable hardware and serves as a decent gaming option on the budget. Plus, the added 5G gives it an edge over its competitors. At a starting price of Rs 14,499, the Poco M3 Pro 5G is a decent purchase for most buyers.

column9: Expect in 2022: More foldable phones now that Samsung Galaxy Z Flip 3 and Oppo Find N are showing the way
column10:
2022 could also be the year when more handset manufacturers announce new foldable devices.

Foldable phones are still rare to find around us, although they have been there for over a couple of years. But, in India, Samsung gave us the first commercially available foldable smartphone, the Galaxy Fold, in 2019. And, now we have seen some newer versions and more handset manufacturers jumping to this form factor. But, some of the problems that have been there stopping foldable phones from leaving a mark in the smartphone industry are their pricing and practical use.

While the pricing may still take a few more years to come down and be more accessible to consumers in the country, practical use is something that has constantly been improving. Thanks to the likes of Samsung, which is largely the only manufacturer investing heavily on foldable phones globally. The good news is that Samsung is finally getting some company from Oppo, Motorola, Huawei, and a few more brands preparing to introduce new foldable devices into the global market.

2022 could be the year to see wider adoption of foldable phones globally, especially in a market like India, where consumers do get foldable smartphone options. For example, Samsung has been selling the Galaxy Z Fold3 5G and Galaxy Z Flip3 5G since last year. Here's why we believe 2022 could be the year when foldable finally gets some appreciation, mostly commercially.

Samsung could lead from the front

If there's one brand that is likely to see maximum traction in the foldable segment, it has to be Samsung, and one of the obvious reasons is the investment it has made so far in this form factor. Both the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold3 and Galaxy Z Flip3 have received rave reviews and are great value products if budget isn't a problem and the consumer wants to try a newer form factor. This year, we expect Samsung to launch the Galaxy Z Fold4 and Galaxy Z Flip4 as successors to the existing line-up of devices available in the market.

Talking about the Samsung Galaxy Z Fold3 first, it features a main screen of 7.6-inches while the cover screen of 6.2-inches offers enough screen space for people who love to use the screen on the go. Powered by Qualcomm Snapdragon 888, the Galaxy Z Fold3 is as powerful as some of the latest Android flagships of 2021. Even in the camera department, the triple camera array featuring three 12-megapixel sensors and selfie cameras on the main and cover screens do not let selfie lovers down. To enhance productivity, the Galaxy Z Fold3 also supports S Pen, and 12GB of RAM offers enough memory to run some of the most demanding apps. Keeping all that running is a 4400mAh battery.

Jumping to the Galaxy Z Flip3, it also offers enough to keep some of the most demanding consumers happy. It features a 6.7-inch main screen while a 1.9-inch cover screen fares well too. The clamshell design has won accolades from reviewers for its usability and manages to play the nostalgia factor nicely.

In 2022, we expect Samsung to continue to set the benchmark for the foldable segment with its newer offerings.

Oppo and others joining the club

Devices like the Oppo Find N are a boon to the foldable segment. Thankfully, we spent some time with the Oppo Find N, which unfortunately isn't launching in India because of the lack of an app ecosystem around foldable devices.

Oppo's Chief Product Officer Pete Lau, during the unveiling, revealed that one big reason why the company chose not to launch the Find N outside China is because of lack of software optimisation and app ecosystem, something that the brand believes it could manage in its homeland. The phone opens up in a landscape mode, which isn't the case with Samsung foldable. What it offers is a more practical design for watching videos, reading e-books, and even playing games. While initially, the 8.4:9 aspect ratio feels unorthodox, as you spend time with it, you realise it is a far better form factor for the foldable segment.

We found it an excellent device in the limited time we spent with the Oppo Find N. It becomes an even better choice when considering the under Rs 1 lakh price. However, it is unfortunate that it didn't make it to India. In 2022, we expect that to change and Oppo to launch the Find N successor in India.

But it's not just Oppo because of which we are excited about. At this point, the rumour mill points to multiple companies working on foldable devices, including Google, Xiaomi, Realme, TCL, and Vivo.

Considering that the foldable segment is still small in sales numbers, the more devices, the merrier it is likely to be.

For the foldable smartphone segment, to woo more consumers, pricing is the key. The Oppo Find N has shown us the way to how it can be achieved. The more aggressive the price foldable gets, the better will be the chances for the device to do well in the markets. The bottom line is that 2022 could be a year when the foldable segment gets some good devices and more consumers adopt them.

column9: Fingers crossed: the AirPods Pro 2 could deliver sweet lossless audio to your ear holes
column10:
Ivan covers Big Tech, India, policy, AI, security, platforms, and apps for TNW. That's one heck of a mixed bag. He likes to say "Bleh." Ivan covers Big Tech, India, policy, AI, security, platforms, and apps for TNW. That's one heck of a mixed bag. He likes to say "Bleh."

It's a new year and there's already a fresh Apple rumor hot off the presses: the upcoming AirPods 2 Pro will support lossless audio streaming. According to a note published by analyst Ming-Chi Kuo, the company is planning a design overhaul of its top-end wireless buds, along with a new case that will beep to help you find it.

The Cupertino-based company launched a lossless music tier for Apple Music last May. But there were only a few ways to enjoy it: if you've got an iPhone, you had to get an external DAC (Digital to Analog Converter) to listen to lossless files; if you've got a Mac or a MacBook, you could technically use a high-end pair of wired headphones to enjoy high-fidelity music.

However, the surprising bit was that none of the AirPods models -- including the $550 AirPods Max -- didn't support lossless audio streaming out of the box. That seemed like an odd choice from Apple. Thankfully, the rumored AirPods Pro 2 could be an answer to that.

While I want to jump with joy, I am keeping my feet firmly on the ground for the time being. Until the new AirPods Pro are out, we would have no idea how they'll improve the audio with Bluetooth's current limitations.

Gary Geaves, Apple's VP of Acoustics, told What Hi-Fi in an interview last week about the wireless standard's bottleneck for audio delivery:

Things like the amount of latency you get when you move your head, and if that's too long, between you moving your head and the sound changing or remaining static, it will make you feel quite ill, so we have to concentrate very hard on squeezing the most that we can out of the Bluetooth technology, and there's a number of tricks we can play to maximize or get around some of the limits of Bluetooth.

But it's fair to say that we would like more bandwidth and... I'll stop right there. We would like more bandwidth.

It would be interesting to see if Apple's solution could be applied to a wider range of wireless audio solutions. Currently, there are some standards such as Qualcomm's AptX and Sony LDAC -- which can transmit audio at a bitrate of 990kbps. You can learn more about bitrate here.

Apple's challenge would be to surpass that and provide the industry best wireless audio experience. If the company manages to do that, it might push other stakeholders, including the Bluetooth Special Interest Group, which manages the standard, to update our beloved Bluetooth wireless spec for better sound.

In the end, the lossless audio support feature might not make a huge difference in the audio quality of the AirPods Pro 2. But it'll hopefully make wireless audio less shitty.

column9: Launched! Just check Vivo Y21T price in India
column10:
Vivo Y21T price is Rs. 16,000 on launch. The phone packs the Snapdragon 680 processor and triple rear camera.

The Vivo Y21T smartphone has been officially launched by Vivo, the Chinese smartphone manufacturer in India days after its debut in Indonesia. The company's Y-series smartphone features a waterdrop-style display notch, Qualcomm's Snapdragon 680 processor, and a triple-rear camera setup with a 50 megapixel primary camera. Vivo Y21T is available in two colours options -- Pearl White and Midnight Blue. Vivo Y21T price has been pegged at around Rs. 16,000. It is available with only one storage configuration with 6GB of RAM and 128GB of internal storage.

While both the Indonesian and Indian versions have the same name, the two have minor differences. The most important distinction is the display, which is a 6.51-inch LCD panel with a resolution of 1600 x 720 pixels and a 60Hz refresh rate in the Indonesian version, while the newly launched in India has a larger 6.58-inch FHD+ display with a 90Hz refresh rate and a 96 percent NTSC colour gamut.

Vivo Y21T has a triple camera setup that has a 50 megapixel primary sensor, a 2 megapixel Bokeh camera, and a 2 megapixel Macro lens at the back. For selfies and video calls, there is a 8 megapixel camera on the front. The smartphone is backed by a 5,000mAh battery with 18W fast charging capabilities. As previously stated, the Vivo Y21T is equipped with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 680 SoC, 128GB of internal storage that can be increased to 1TB, and 4GB of RAM with 1GB of virtual memory expansion. A side-mounted fingerprint sensor, FunTouch OS 12 based on Android 11, and liquid cooling technology, USB-C, 3.5mm headphone jack, a dual SIM slot are among the other features.

Talking about its looks and design, the smartphone comes with a 2.5D flat frame and 8mm thin body, which weighs around 182 grams. At the back, you will see the pearl lustre with a hint of pink for Pearl White model whereas the Midnight Blue colour comes in a sophisticated frosted surface with a subtle shine allowing the deep shade of blue to overpower the look at the back.

The price of Vivo Y21T for India isn't announced yet. But keeping in mind the price of the model in Indonesia, Y21T which is price at IDR 3,099,000 is expected to be available around Rs. 16,000 in India.

column9: Here's when Samsung's upcoming AMD-powered Exynos chip will launch
column10:
AMD's GPU architecture also powers the Xbox Series X and Sony PlayStation 5's graphics.

Samsung seems to be all set to take the wraps off its next-generation Exynos processor, which will include an AMD-powered GPU; the South Korean tech giant has announced that its Exynos 2100 successor will see the light of day next week.

In a tweet, Samsung confirmed that it will hold an event on January 11 for the unveiling of its next Exynos chip featuring a new GPU based on AMD's RDNA 2. For the uninitiated, the RDNA 2 graphics architecture is the same GPU used in the Xbox Series X, Sony PlayStation 5, and AMD's Radeon RX 6000 graphics cards.

AMD announced earlier last year that it would bring the RDNA2 architecture to the mobile segment. However, the chipset isn't expected to deliver the same level of graphics performance to Samsung's future phones that it does to some of the best video game consoles. Nonetheless, Samsung promised improved gaming performance with the upcoming processor, which will bring ray tracing and variable rate shading to mobile devices.

The incorporation of AMD graphics into the Exynos processor is not surprising. In 2019, Samsung announced a collaboration with the semiconductor company to use Radeon graphics in its mobile processors.

The teaser didn't specifically mention the Exynos 2200 moniker, but that's what the next-generation SoC will most likely be called. It's also expected to power Samsung's best Android phones in 2022, such as the upcoming Galaxy S22 series, though this SoC is likely to be limited to global versions of the phone, with US models presumably using Qualcomm's Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 chipset.

It's worth noting that this is the first Exynos chipset to include an AMD-powered GPU, indicating that Samsung intends to compete with Qualcomm's Snapdragon and Apple's mobile chipsets.

column9: Defying Covid, CES Tech Trade Show Opens This Week in Las Vegas
column10:
Despite a surge in Covid-19 cases across the country, the annual CES tech trade show.

It's a daring decision by the Consumer Technology Association, the industry trade group that sponsored the annual extravaganza -- one that runs the risk of creating a superspreader event. CTA President Gary Shapiro contends the company has taken every possible safety precaution, requiring vaccinations and masks, and handing out self-test kits to all attendees. CES was held in an all-virtual format in January 2021

Many larger companies have withdrawn from in-person participation in the show. T-Mobile US (ticker: TMUS ) CEO Mike Sievert canceled a planned keynote, and General Motors ( GM ) CEO Mary Barra will deliver her keynote virtually. Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), Intel (INTC), Mercedes, Meta ( FB ), Procter & Gamble (PG), Lenovo, Advanced Micro Devices ( AMD ), and many others have decided not to participate in person. Many news outlets have also opted out of live coverage, including tech publications such as CNET, Engadget, and the Verge. But despite many predictions to the contrary, CTA declined to cancel CES.

"CES will and must go on," Shapiro wrote . "It will have many more small companies than large ones. It may have big gaps on the show floor. Certainly, it will be different from previous years. It may be messy. But innovation is messy. It is risky and uncomfortable. I view CES as representing the best of our unique American history -- a place where those who are different and have big ideas can gather. Where success is not based on class or religion or anything but the strength of an idea."

Shapiro added that canceling the show would "hurt thousands of smaller companies, entrepreneurs and innovators who have made investments in building their exhibits and are counting on CES for their business, inspiration and future."

Key themes at this year's event will include autonomous and electric vehicles, health and wellness products and the development of the metaverse. Keynote speakers will include Qualcomm (QCOM) CEO Cristiano Amon, Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg, Abbott Laboratories (ABT) CEO Robert Ford and Samsung Electronics CEO Jong-Hee Han, in addition to GM's Barra. Peloton Interactive (PTON) CEO John Foley will speak at the CTA's annual "Leaders in Technology" dinner.

But the biggest story at CES 2022 undoubtedly will be how event organizers, exhibitors, and attendees cope with Covid. Focus will be on the effectiveness of CTA's safety protocols, the smaller crowds, and personal choices on whether to attend the event at all.

The CES show floor will be open for three days, down from the usual four, starting on Wednesday -- on Friday, CTA announced that it was reducing this year's event by a day. "The step was taken as an additional safety measure to the current health protocols that have been put in place for CES," CTA said. A few companies have been shifted to virtual press events -- including Bosch, Hisense, and Intel (INTC).

This year's event will include the CES debut of a new section of the Las Vegas Convention Center, the West Hall; CES won't be using the Old South Hall of the LVCC. One way to get around will be via built by Elon Musk's Boring Co. that ferries passengers via Tesla ( TSLA ) vehicles. Exhibition space in The Venetian will again host another group of exhibitors, while press day events will take place at the Mandalay Bay convention center.

Barron's plans to provide updates from the event throughout the week.

Write to Eric J. Savitz at

column9: Vivo Y21T Launched With Triple Rear Cameras: Price, Specifications  - Pragativadi
column10:
New Delhi: Vivo has added an affordable smartphone named Vivo Y21T to its Y series. The latest Vivo phone comes with a waterdrop-style display notch and triple rear cameras. Vivo Y21T also carries a Qualcomm Snapdragon 680 SoC and is equipped with 18W fast charging support. The smartphone comes in two distinct colours to choose from. Vivo Y21T is also rumoured to debut in India next week, with some distinction.

Price

Vivo Y21T comes in only 6GB + 128GB storage option which is costs IDR 3,099,000 (about Rs 16,200). It is available for pre-order in Midnight Blue and Pearl White color options.

The India launch of the Vivo Y21T is yet to be confirmed. However, there are reports that this smartphone can be launched with a 4GB + 128GB storage variant for Rs 16,490.

Specifications

Talking about the specification, it comes with a 6.51-inch LCD panel with 1600×720 pixel resolution, which has a refresh rate of 60Hz. This display given in the phone comes with an aspect ratio of 20: 9. In the Indian variant of the phone, the company can offer a 6.58-inch display with 2408×1080 pixel resolution, which will have a refresh rate of 90Hz.

In Indonesia, the company has launched this phone with 6 GB RAM + 128 GB internal storage. It also has 2 GB of virtual RAM. This phone can come with 4 GB RAM and 1 GB Extended RAM in India.

The newly launched Vivo Y21T has a triple rear camera setup, including 50-megapixel primary camera with f/1.8 aperture, a 2-megapixel secondary sensor, and a 2-megapixel depth sensor. The phone has an 8-megapixel selfie camera for clicking selfies and video calling.
